Quoted Line: “These waters, rolling from their mountain-springs…” (*Tintern Abbey*, 1798)
What It Signified Then: River as sacred, self-renewing force of beauty and reflection.
Present-Day Ecological Reality: River Wye, once pristine, now heavily polluted by phosphates and agricultural runoff; algal blooms causing fish deaths. Globally, rivers face droughts, pollution, and water scarcity (WMO 2023).

Quoted Line: “...later flowers for the bees / Until they think warm days will never cease…” (*To Autumn*, 1819)
What It Signified Then: Autumnal abundance; harmony between nature’s cycles and human joy.
Present-Day Ecological Reality: Global pollinator populations declining; ~75% of food crops depend on pollination. IPBES confirms strong regional declines due to land use and pesticides.

Quoted Line: “All felled, felled, are all felled…” (*Binsey Poplars*, 1879)
What It Signified Then: Spiritual lament for deforestation; trees as divine beauty.
Present-Day Ecological Reality: Since 1990, ~420 million ha forest lost (FAO). Global tree cover loss 517 million ha since 2001 (Global Forest Watch).

Quoted Line: “Old pond / a frog jumps in — sound of water.” (1686)
What It Signified Then: Symbol of quiet vitality, harmony, and presence of life.
Present-Day Ecological Reality: ~41% of amphibian species threatened (IUCN 2023). Wetlands globally degraded or disappearing due to pollution and habitat loss.

Quoted Line: Detailed observations of ice-out, bloom, and animal activity (*Walden*, 1854)
What It Signified Then: Seasonal cycles representing balance and self-reliance.
Present-Day Ecological Reality: Walden Pond now shows 5°F temperature rise; earlier flowering and ice melt (Primack et al., Harvard study). Climate change shifting seasonal rhythms worldwide.

Quoted Line: “I raise the cup to invite the moon…” (*Drinking Alone under the Moon*, 8th c.)
Present-Day Ecological Reality: ~80% of North Americans and 60% of Europeans can no longer see the Milky Way due to light pollution (Falchi et al., Science Advances).

Quoted Line: Skylarks and nightingales as voices of transcendence.
What It Signified Then: Birdsong as symbol of pure joy and divine connection.
Present-Day Ecological Reality: 3 billion birds lost in North America since 1970 (Science 2019). Freshwater vertebrates declined 83% since 1970 (WWF 2022).
